column1: IS 430:Fundamentals of IT Project Management:This course concentrates on monitoring
column2: managing and controlling assets and resources on a single IT project.  Topics covered are risk management; procurement and contract management; time and cost estimating; controlling and tracking techniques; quality assurance; testing and audit.  Students will use common project management software for resource allocation and balancing. PREREQUISITE(S)  None::S1O

column1: ECT 424:Enterprise Infrastructure:Introduction to modern infrastructure and the evolving technology environment.  Major topics include  computer networks
column3: Web 2.0

column1: IS 556:Enterprise Project Management:This course covers how an enterprise coordinates and effectively manages all its IT projects and programs through program management and the IT program management office.  Students will learn the role of the IT program management office in establishing and maintaining the project and program infrastructure and in assisting project managers
column3: and the executive steering committee.  Students will analyze the role of program management in coordinating the delivery of expected program benefits
column5: and in establishing program governance.  PREREQUISITE(S)  IS 430 or PM 430:IS 430 or PM 430:SpO

column1: IS 570:Enterprise System Implementation:Formerly IS 450.  This course is targeted towards information systems professionals who are involved in the planning and implementation of large scale
column2: cross-functional enterprise systems.  Students will examine the characteristics of technology efforts that change and transform the way people perform their tasks and how the new technology structures the flows of information and decision making using workflow modeling methods.   Through case studies and exercises students gain insights into the elements of successful implementations leading to the preparation of a change management plan.  Emphasis is placed on developing mechanisms for communicating and training all affected agents.  PREREQUISITE(S)   IS 430 or PM 430 or completion of five or more other SoC MS level courses should contact the course instructor or an advisor.:IS 430 or PM 430 or completion of five or more other SoC MS level courses should contact the course instructor or an advisor:S2O

column3: tactical and strategic levels.  Students will learn how to apply a variety of financial methods -- breakeven analysis
column6: and return on investment to various IT investment decisions. The course will also address cost benefit analysis
column11: and IT investment portfolio methods.  These techniques will prepare students to manage capital budgets

column1: CNS 440:Information Security Management:Survey of information security management as it applies to information systems analysis

column4: as well as the process of developing
column9: and guidelines. Identifying and evaluating information assets

column16: and risk management; security policies and standards; security audits; access controls; network perimeter protection
column17: data protection; physical security; security education training and awareness. Introduction to compliance
column18: as well as the CISSP domains.  PREREQUISITE(S)  None::SpO

column1: ECT 556:Enterprise Architecture and Design:This is an advanced course on the design and planning of enterprise architecture that enables intra-/multi-enterprise collaboration and interoperability.  The emphasis is on the alignment between IT and organizational objectives through the integration of business architectures
column3: application architecture
column5: interfaces and infrastructure. Topics include  frameworks
column7: and methodologies for enterprise architecture design; data and process modeling
column11: and managing costs of implementation. Students will conduct case studies and develop architecture plans. Prerequisites  ECT 424 and SE 430:::3

column1: IS 440:Collaborative Technologies for Leading Projects:Study of the process of virtual teaming with emphasis on facilitation of different time project activities and facilitation of same time meetings.  Students will learn how small group psychology and group communication theories inform specific behaviors in the design and leadership of meetings.  Several meeting types including information briefing
column3: document writing
column6: and teaching/training will be explored.  In addition
column7: the course surveys current collaboration technologies and discusses how to select among those technologies usability and fit to purpose of a meeting agenda.  DL students may be required to schedule same time sessions with the instructor and other DL students; see current quarter syllabus for more information on this point.  PREREQUISITE(S)  None::SpO

column1: IS 483:Information Services and Operations:This course focuses on the operational aspects of information systems in organizations by examining the concepts
column2: tools and techniques available to IS professionals responsible for the delivery of IT services.  Topics include the organization of the IT services; the procurement of hardware
column3: software and vendor services; operation of data centers
column5: the development and use of RFPs (Request for Proposals) and SLAs (Service Level Agreements)
column6: the integration of services and operations with application development project needs
column7: and the role of capital and operating budgets.  PREREQUISITE(S)   Completion of five or more SoC MS level courses is required.:Completion of five or more SoC MS level courses is required:WiO

column1: IS 500:Information Technology Leadership:Managing people ethically and effectively by applying a broad range of creative approaches to individual and team leadership within an Information Technology context.  Leadership methods studied include trait-based
column3: situational
column10: as well as team leadership and the international
column12: and ethical dimensions of leadership.  Students assess their leadership styles and design individualized development plans to strengthen existing skills and expand IT leadership capabilities by incorporating additional leadership dimensions.  PREREQUISITE(S)  IS 430 OR PM 430 OR SE 477:IS 430 OR PM 430 OR SE 477:SpO

column1: MGT 500:Managing for Effective and Ethical Organizational Behavior:Students will critically examine ethical and creative methods to solve problems related to managing individuals and teams. Students utilize feedback from a developmental assessment center assessing their managerial and interpersonal skills. Personal development plans are created and skills developed throughout the course. Skill development domains include perception
column3: motivation
column10: and business ethics. Reserved for Kellstadt students or CDM students in select programs. Reserved for Kellstadt students or CDM students in select programs.::S1O

column1: IS 505:Business Continuity/Disaster Recovery Theories and Strategies:This course focuses on the knowledge necessary for an organization to prepare for a variety of major disruptions (floods
column3: terrorist attacks
column4: etc.).  The goal is survival of the organization and its daily workflow despite major disruption.  Students learn to analyze and prioritize risks and determine criticality ratings that are used to determine survival strategies.  Students also learn how to organize employees to respond to a major disruption and how to document recovery plans.  Course content includes coverage of current industry trends
column5: as well as planning for the survival of Information Technology functions within an organization.::S1O

column1: IS 506:Business Continuity/Disaster Recovery Management and Tactics:The course prepares students to lead an organization's business continuity and disaster recovery plans.  Students learn the methodology needed to organize this function within an organization
column2: evaluate an organization's business continuity and disaster recovery program according to established industry standards
column3: and conduct a variety of quick-recovery drills.  Students also focus upon industry-related human resources issues
column5: and policies and procedures for setting up a command center. Course content includes coverage of current industry trends
column6: as well as managing the survival of Information Technology functions within an organization.  PREREQUISITE(S)   IS 505:IS 505:S2O

column1: IS 565:IT Outsourcing:The course focuses on how organizations can use leverage of scale as a source for cost reduction; leverage of expertise for improved superior IT performance; leverage of access (e.g. location) to develop new strategies. column2: sourcing maturity levels and best practices. PREREQUISITE(S)  Completion of five or more SoC MS level courses is required:Completion of five or more SoC MS level courses is required:WiO

column1: IS 580:Technology Entrepreneurship:In-depth examination of the entrepreneurial process within technology intensive ventures. Roles of entrepreneurs and their start-up teams. Suitable business models and strategies. Legal issues and intellectual property. Financial issues and venture resources. Role of the customer and entrepreneurial marketing. Students will analyze and present case studies of technology entrepreneurial ventures. Students will develop a marketing plan and a business plan for a technology-intensive entrepreneurial venture of their choice.  PREREQUISITE(S)  Completion of the foundation phase.:Completion of the foundation phase:SpO:3

column8: strategic applications and strategic IT planning. Students are encouraged to take this course toward the end of their study.  PREREQUISITE(S) Completion of ten or more SoC MS level courses is required.::S1O
